A momen later she reappears with a CAT, an orange tabby, and puts on the inner sill. Montag watches, increasingly puzzled. The cat patiently endures as Clarisse puts a little red c hat on him with a rubber band strap, then slips his hind into little cowboy boots. Done, Clarisse stands the kitty on its hind legs and "puppets" him in a goofy little danc The image is so absurd and unexpected, Montag can't help laughing. Clarisse smiles at his reaction, happy. Softly:
Now that's just...silly. She makes the cat wave goodbye. Montag walks on... CuT TO:

-and we're plunged into a cauldron of NOISE: Firemen shou as bets are made, insults traded. DILLMAN, LANDERS, PECK, ORMSBY, and a DOZEN OTHERS are clustered around six wire on the firehouse floor, each containing a LARGE SEWER RAT Before them stands the Mechanical Hound, waiting. As the men jostle and shout, Dillman raises a cage to sho everybody the aggressive, hissing rat within. The cage ha handwritten number "3" on it.
Who's it gonna be? Horse number three? Let's see some money!
Look at that mean son of a bitch! That's him, that's my bad boy!
You're gonna lose your shirt, Peck!
Fifty bucks says you can kiss my ass!
A bargain! Your wife charges a hundred!

Go on, Dillman, give it a whiff! Dillman holds the cage out, letting the Mechanical Hound the rat. To a nose as finely calibrated as the Hound's, t rat's scent is as good as a DNA fingerprint. (The data ap on Ormsby's plasma-screen next to "Horse #3: Peck's Bad B
Got it! Next! Dillman dumps the rat out of the cage to join two others already in the "starting gate" -- a round bottomless hold pen on the floor. He reaches for the next cage while:
sit on a cot apart from the others, speaking quietly:
Thank you for helping last night.
Thank me no thankings, nor proud me no prouds. It's nothing.
I came close to losing her. If you hadn't intervened...
And how's Millie? Okay? (Montag hesitates) Tell me.
She won't talk about it. She won't even admit it happened.

Maybe that's a good thing. If she doesn't remember, I doubt she intended to harm herself. That's what's got you worried, yes? (Montag nods) She probably just lost track. It happens. Never happened to you?
I don't take levelers.
Really? I never knew that. Montag, I'm surprised at you. It's the shortcut to bliss, haven't you seen the ads? Everybody takes levelers.
Do you?

(wry) I like a little misery now and again. (Montag laughs softly) Ah, a smile, thank God. There's the old Montag. I was beginning to worry. Dillman dumps the last rat into the holding pen, raises h arms to quiet the men:

Welcome to Rat Dome! Six rats enter...one rat leaves! Mr. Ormsby, program the Hound for five kills in random order, if you please! Who will the lucky survivor be? Final bets, place your final bets! (calls over) Montag, you in?
Not tonight.
(offering) And we know our dear captain never wagers...
I prefer sure things to guesswork. But thank you, Mr. Dillman.
In that case, the betting window is closed! Horses are at the gate! A boisterous countdown begins:
Dillman kicks the holding pen over, freeing the rats --

And they're off! -- which scatter in all directions, men jumping and shout as rats go zipping past their feet. Ormsby hits "send." The Hound's eyes go infra-red. Pandem ensues as the Hound springs into action and streaks acros the firehouse like a guided missile...

...and catches the first rat within seconds, snatching it in its jaws and shaking its chrome head so fast that the flies apart in its teeth. (That rat's data entry turns re Ormsby's screen.) The Hound veers and goes after the next rat, men running and shouting and jumping out of the way
It's not just the incident last night, is it? There's something else troubling you.
We don't seem to talk much at all any more. I feel like we've drifted, but...I don't know why. Or what to do about it. I try.
makes another kill. Another entry on Ormsby's screen turn red. The men shout like spectators at a football game.
Perhaps I can make our human resources department available to you. Therapy, counseling...
Those benefits are for ranking officers only.
Well, I wasn't going to spill these beans just yet...
kills another rat, veers after the next.

++. but I've decided to nominate you as my replacement when I retire. That means promotion. Captain Montag, how does that sound? I'll suggest they advance you some of those benefits. With your record, and your promising future, I'm sure DHS will see things my way. Montag is blown away by this news. Beatty leans in.
You're special, Montag. Command caliber. That makes you a deeply valuable asset to this department.
I don't know what to say.

(smiles) Someday, my boy, all this will be yours. Including the rats... (his gaze shifts) .--oh, hell. A rat zips under their cot, the Hound in pursuit. They le to their feet as the Hound barrels between them, sending cot spinning into the air to the delighted howls of the m We hear a SQUEAL as the fifth rat is killed. Its data ent goes red, leaving one. The Hound pauses, awaiting further instructions. Amidst the jeers and laughter:
Too bad, Peck. That was your bad boy. Peck bends down and sees the sixth and final rat pressed against the wall under a desk, panting in terror.
And the winner is?
Horse #2, "Dillman's Delight."
Ohhh, what a heartbreak! Sorry, boys, fork it over! I hate to say it, but I am the winnaahh...
Take your money and shut your pie- hole, Dillman. Suddenly, the ALARM SOUNDS. The men react, scattering as:
Gentlemen, fun's over! Kindly dispose of the winner. Ormsby quickly enters a kill command. The Hound bounds ac the floor and pounces on the last SHRIEKING rat as we
HUGE DOORS slide open, revealing the Salamander in a glar lights. It rumbles out, SIREN WAILING. The control van fo

A three-story Victorian relic stands like a ghost from an era just outside the downtown financial district, skyscra looming in the misty sky b.g. The vacant lots in this area have become Hoovervilles of future -- shanty towns filled with HOMELESS PEOPLE living tents and cardboard boxes. Cookfires are drifting smoke. Searchlights suddenly blaze from the sky as HOVERCOPTERS appear. The homeless begin to panic as the SIREN of the Salamander comes swelling up the street.
(from hovercopter)

head_text.subj: REMAIN CALM. THIS IS A ROUTINE FIRE
ALARM. REMAIN CALM OR RIOT TROOPS

text: pulls up before the Victorian house. The control van veer past it, taking up position as police vehicles arrive to provide backup. Some of the homeless start drifting this from their shanty towns, drawn by the promise of a fire. Firemen jump down from the truck, marching across the str of dead lawn past a PAIR OF STONE LIONS. This house might have been a library once, a few hundred years ago. The battering rams are readied as the men take positions the door. Beatty knocks. For a moment there's nothing. Be is about to motion them to break the door down, but then: A face appears at the window, ethereal and beautiful. It' OLD WOMAN, her eyes luminous, her skin like worn silk. She motions for Beatty to be patient. The face withdraws. few seconds pass. We hear the door UNLOCKING from inside. It opens, revealing the old woman. Her smile is enigmatic if she's merely receiving visitors.
Good evening.
Madam. We have a warrant.

Of course you do. Everything all nice and legal and proper. Nobody's rights shall be violated this evening, I'm sure. (swings the door wider) Please do come in. Mind you wipe your feet. Montag and the others are trading glances. This is differ

The firemen enter and spread out a bit, gazing up. We're grand entry foyer that soars three stories up, surrounded all sides by landings. The staircase railings are carved the lighting is Tiffany stained glass, the furnishings ar ancient as the house. A grandfather clock TICKS SOFTLY.
I've been expecting you.
Have you indeed?
For many years. I've often tried to imagine your face. Now I know. Beatty raises his plasma-screen clipboard.
Name?
You may call me Mrs. Havisham, if that pleases you. And I might call you Pip. Yes, that might be quite amusing. (off his look) Don't insult my intelligence. You know my name.
(checks his screen) Mrs. Roland. I am Captain Beatty. We've received an anonymous tip...
Is there any other kind?
...which empowers us by law to conduct a search for books.
And you shall find them, I'm sure. In the walls. The attic. Under the floors. Don't forget to check the cupboards.
Montag. Have the men proceed, and see the lady out.

Five teams of three! Carillo, Peck, first and second floors! Dillman, third! Landers, basement! Ormsby, attic! Go! The teams split up, double-timing. The old woman watches go. Montag offers his hand to escort her out.
Ma'am? Please come with me.
I most certainly will not. Nor may you coerce me. Isn't that right, Captain?
Dear lady, let's have no foolishness. Accompany the fireman, he'll see you safely out. Please don't make me insist.
Insist all you like. I am perfectly within my legal rights, as you well know. Montag throws Beatty a puzzled look. Beatty gives the old woman an appraising look, motions Montag to wait.
According to whom? She pulls a book from her pocket, paging through it.

Your own Homeland Security manual. One of the few books not on the burning list. I've read it many times with great interest, especially the section on your department. (pauses to read) "The fire department was established in 1790 to burn English-influenced ° (MORE)

books in the Colonies. The first fireman: Benjamin Franklin." Oh, I do so love history. (keeps paging) Let's see. Ah, here it is. I have it marked. Chapter twelve, subsection four. According to the Supreme Court decision granting the government full authority as regards the burning of books for purposes of national security, the accused -- that would be me -- has the right to remain present and bear full witness. She closes the book and tucks it away.
That's an extremely obscure and seldom-invoked right .

Nevertheless, I invoke it. {off Beatty's look) They're your rules. You must abide by them. A moment of stand-off. Beatty gazing at the woman. The wo unflinching. Montag uncertain, caught between them.
Montag. Scan the lady, if you please. Montag pulls his x-ray wand, running it up and down the w body. Beatty clicks his comlink...
Control?
-..and we see x-ray images coming over the monitors -- bo veins, swirls of cloth. The computers give readouts and percentages: "Cotton Fiber, Elastics, Organic Material,"
No concealed weapons...no incendiary devices...
(over comlink, filtered) -.-She's clean.
You may stay until I order in the flamethrowers. That is when your right expires and you shall be removed for your own safety. Until then, Fireman Montag will remain at your side.
That is satisfactory. Montag shakes his head -- this is crazy. Beatty glances u a VOICE comes over his comlink:
(filtered) Cap! You're not gonna believe this...
Dillman and his team are sweeping the hallway walls with wands, mouths agape, the ghostly x-ray images revealing: Books. And more books. Endless rows of them within the wa
The controllers are watching, amazed. The monitors show x images of books everywhere throughout the house. Softly:
Holy Christ. Look at ‘em all.
Dillman appears at the third floor railing above.
They're everywhere. The whole house...
(over comlink, filtered) Landers, sir, confirming that. Must be thousands.
Get on with it. AXES AND CHAINSAWS rip the walls... CEILINGS are torn open with long pikes... FLOORBOARDS are sundered with pry bars... SHELVES are overturned, furniture smashed...

replays the opening image of our film: In SLO-MO, an object falls through frame -- a book. Rolli tumbling, dropping from sight. Another book. And another. Books falling. And soon: Raining. It's raining books. ANGLE TILTS DOWN to reveal t old woman watching the books falling all around her. She to Montag, meets his gaze. Softly:
Why do you want to see this?
They're my books. Montag catches a book as it falls, looks up to see:
throwing armloads of books over the railings. They rain d cascading, fluttering like birds. Montag takes the old wo by the elbow, guides her gently to a safer position...
..-while the Scooper dumps another load of books onto the beacon and backs away...

..-.and boots come pounding as firemen enter with kerosen pumpers on their backs, fanning out. ANGLE SHIFTS TO Montag watching the old woman. She's taki it all in, her expression inscrutable... All around them, throughout the house, firemen soak the w the heaps of books, priming the house like a bomb... The fumes are getting thick. Montag snaps his breather ma over his face, takes a few deep breaths. He pulls the mas away, offers it to the woman.
No thank you. She pulls a handkerchief, holds it over her nose and mout A few firemen are gathering at Beatty's side, pumpers emp Montag, cued by a look from Beatty, clicks his comlink:
Gentlemen, wrap it up.
Dillman's pumper goes dry. He motions "let's go" to the o as he clicks his comlink:
We're done here! Heading down now!
Beatty turns to the old woman:
The flamethrowers are next. It's time to leave. She meets his gaze, her eyes watering from the fumes.
You can't ever have my books.
(gently) Books aren't real. Only the law is real. Come on now.
I'd rather stay.
You know I can't allow that. Suicide is also against the law.
Ma'am. This whole house is gonna go up. Come on. I'll walk you out.
No.
I'm counting to ten. If you don't leave, my men will pick you up and carry you out. One...two...
It'll be okay. Just come with me.
...three...four...
Thank you anyway.
...five...six...
(offering his hand) Please.
Go on. I'll be fine.
...seven...eight...
.-Shut the gate... She reaches up, undoing her bun. Her hair unravels as she pulls a small, slender object from it...
..-nine...ten... ...and she holds the object out toward them...
..a big fat hen. ---it's an ordinary kitchen match. Her thumbnail poised o the sulfur tip. The men draw back, stunned.
Panic erupts, voices shouting and overlapping:
--where the hell did that come from--
--get 'em out, get 'em out of there--
(on comlink) --all personnel evacuate the building immediately! Suspect has a match...
FIREMEN react, horrified, breaking and running for the ex
(on comlink, filtered) ..-repeat, suspect has a match! Evacuate the building now!
...while the old woman backs Montag, Beatty, and the othe firemen toward the door with her match.
{calm, steely) Gentlemen, you heard the order. Evacuate. The others rush out, but Montag stays. He and Beatty keep backing slowly toward the door as:
Allow me to appeal to your reason. Where's the sense in this?
Where's the sense in anything? The world's gone upside down.
The world is fine, it's your mind that's upside down. See what those books have done to you?
Ma'am. This is crazy. You don't want to do this.
This is my home. And these are my books. Get out. Now. (as they hesitate)
Montag and Beatty back out the door...
...onto the front porch. A VOICE comes over Beatty's coml
(filtered) The police have a sniper! Should we take her out? Beatty throws Montag a long-suffering look, clicks his co

That would defeat the purpose now, wouldn't it? I'm certain Mrs. Roland will see reason, once she's had a chance to think it through. Isn't that right, dear? The old woman turns away, walking back to the center of t xoom, gazing around at the wreckage, the piles of books. tries to go back inside to grab her, but Beatty puts a restraining hand on his arm.

Mrs. Roland? You've made your point. Given everyone a good scare. Well done. Time to come out now. She turns, facing them. A long look passes between them a her thumbnail tightens on the match head...
Play the man, Master Ridley; we shall this day light such a candle, by God's grace, in England, as I trust shall never be put out.

(a whisper) Don't. ---and her thumbnail scrapes the sulfur tip, FLARING it t life. Montag's eyes widen in horror -- -- and the match flare leaps into the air, a heartbeat of white-hot ignition, the air rippling as it catches fire. a moment the old woman is surrounded by an aura of flame swirling about her, lifting her hair and catching it afir making her eyes glow like coals -- -- and BOOOOM! The entryway EXPLODES, shattering windows, HUGE FIST OF FLAME punching through the front door and bl Beatty and Montag right off their feet, hurling them over railings and onto the lawn in a storm of debris. Some oth firemen are caught on the run, also blown off their feet.
A firestorm surges up the stairs...races along the walls...engulfing room after room...shattering the grandf clock with heat...consuming piles of books...
Montag pries his face off the lawn, sees Beatty sitting u next to him with his pant leg on fire. Frantic, Montag he smother the flames as Beatty yells into his comlink:
Did everybody get out?
(filtered) All links are active! Everybody's fine! Montag turns, gazing at the house through a pall of smoke swirling embers, and sees:
An inferno within. A FIGURE appears in the flames. A burn woman. Staggering in the blast-furnace. Tripping and fall Then gone in a rush of flame.
staring in horror.
come running against a backdrop of flames, pulling Beatty Montag to their feet, rushing them away as the house burn
Riding back to the firehouse. Faces grim.
Gear is being cleaned and stowed. The mood is subdued, qu Montag backs the Scooper off the firetruck, parks it. As gets off, Beatty enters and activity comes to a standstil

Most of you have never seen a suicide. They were far more common in the old days. Just understand there is no accounting for unstable minds. You all followed protocol and did your jobs well. Nobody here is to blame. Glances are traded. Nobody feels good about what happened tonight. Softly:
I missed it. The match. When I scanned her.

Then it's your fault? I see. Or is it mine, for failing to instruct you to scan her hair? I was officer in charge, after all. Blame, if any, lies with me. My report will say so. But Montag. I was not the old woman who stood in a house primed with kerosene and chose to light a match. Nor were you. Nor (MORE)
were any of us. That act of insanity lies solely with her. Yes? Montag nods. Beatty motions to the group.
Let's put it behind us. That gear isn't going to stow itself, is it? The men disperse, activity resuming as:
(grumbling) I dunno what we're all twisted up over. Stupid old bitch could'a got us all killed. I'm glad she burned.
Leave it alone, Peck. Give us a break...
secures the Scooper, attaching the tiedowns, as Beatty co up behind him:
All done?
I still have to recharge the fuel cells.
No. I mean, blaming yourself. All done? . Montag hesitates, nods. Beatty starts to move off, but:
Master Ridley. That crazy thing she said. Play the game, something, something.
"Play the man, Master Ridley. We shall this day light such a candle, by God's grace, in England, as I trust shall never be put out." Some firemen nearby pause, startled.

A man named Latimer said that to a man named Nicholas Ridley as they were being burnt alive at Oxford, for heresy, in 1555. (off their looks) Oh, I'm full of bits and pieces. Most fire captains are, after doing it enough years. The nonsense sticks to your boots like chewing gum. (to Montag) But nonsense is all it is. Romantic, foolish notions that appeal to feeble minds and justify idiot behavior such as suicide. (leans in, softly) Go home, Montag. Hug your wife. Beatty departs. Montag moves to the front of the Scooper connect the hydrogen fuel hose... ---and stops. There, lying in the scoop blade, are TWO BO that _got left behind when the last load was dumped.
. (suddenly appears) Need help?
Um...no. Got it. Thanks. Ormsby leaves. Montag connects the fuel coupling, moves o

-.,and we find Montag sitting before his locker after a s toweling his hair. He looks numb. The place is emptying, doors shutting, voices drifting off, firemen heading home He becomes aware of Dillman down the row, lacing his boot look passes between them. It's clear both men are stunned deeply shaken. Softly, so only Montag can hear:

I can't get it out of my head. You? Montag shakes his head. No, he can't. Almost embarrassed, Dillman grabs his gym bag and leaves. Montag is left alone. He rises to his locker, lifts his fireman's necklace from its peg, drapes it around his nec CuT TO:

Montag slides down the brass pole, moves through the shad past the Salamander. This part of the firehouse is desert MUFFLED VOICES can be heard from the floor above, followe occasional bursts of raucous laughter. Montag's drawn inexorably to the Scooper. He stops, peers into the scooper blade, sees the two books lying in shado He's frozen, unsure. He reaches in and pulls one out. It' "Charlie the Choo Choo," by Beryl Evans. A children's boo He pulls out the other one. "Lord of the Flies," by Willi Golding. Neither title means anything to him, but the boo themselves have him transfixed. Quickly, before he can change his mind, he shoves the boo into his gym bag, heads for the exit...

---and as he rounds the corner, comes face to face with t Mechanical Hound. The beast is lying there, head resting its paws. Montag freezes. The Hound raises its head, looking like an exotic chromed Sphinx. Its glowing red eyes abruptly dilate wider with a soft WHIRRR. To Montag's astonishment, a LOW GROWL builds the Hound's throat.

Easy, boy. Easy now. Montag takes a nervous step back. The Hound rises and com forward, sniffing the air... Its titanium jaws open, gleaming. The hypodermic tongue distends, slowly at first, then flicking forward and back forward and back -- snap, snap, snap! A drop of amber flu flies off the needle tip, hits the floor.
sit. Goddamn it, I said sit. The Hound hesitates, backs off. Its haunches lower and th beast lies back down, but remains coiled like a spring.
Good boy. Stay. Stay. The Hound stays. Montag circles past it, out the door...

The latest war news is playing on the VID SCREENS. Images floating HOVERTANKS skimming desert sands in some far off land. Muzzle blasts. Explosions. Stirring theme music. PAN TO Montag waiting for his train. A PAIR OF BEAT COPS their urban armor are crossing the platform toward him. T see his fireman's uniform, pass him with a nod. He nods b cur TO:
Montag rides the train, paranoia growing. People seem to staring at him. He turns away, looks out the window. cuT To:

Montag walks home, gym bag in hand. In the far b.g., a POLICE CAR appears, cruising slowly in the intersection. Montag glances back and keeps walking, praying the car will continue on through the intersection But no, the police car turns, coming this way. Montag kee walking, slowly, forcing himself to appear nonchalant. Bu the moment he turns the corner...

..-he breaks into a full run. Feet pounding the pavement, bag flying at his side. He drops the gym bag. Shit! He skids to a stop, grabs it, goes darting down the next intersecting street. A moment later, the police car appears around the corner. pedestrian they were tailing is gone. The car accelerates toward us, LIGHTS FLASHING...

..as Montag comes running, hearing the police car racing toward the intersection behind him. He dives for cover behind some trash cans lining the side squeezing into the shadows between the cans and a fence. The police car swerves into view around the corner. Slowi SPOTLIGHTS blaze to life as the vehicle comes creeping up street toward us, probing the shadows.
as the lights grow brighter, nearer. He's gasping to catc his breath. Suddenly:

(whispering) Don't breathe so loud. They have microphones. Montag turns his head. The fence he's squeezed up against Clarisse's. He can see her eyes through the cracks in the boards -- she's crouched on the other side. The car draws parallel with them, the dazzling glare of t spotlight probing from the other side of the trash cans. The car stops. Faint, ghostly RADIO CHATTER spills into t night. We hear murmurs:

I got sound and motion. Something back there. Montag's frozen, trying not to move or breathe. Suddenly, from the other side of the fence comes a MEOW. Clarisse's skitters along the fence in the shadows.
Goddamn cat. The car moves on, spotlight plying the shadows. Montag wa it disappear down the street. In whispers:
Why are you hiding?
I did something tonight. Something very stupid.
What?
I took some books. No response at first. He shifts his head so he can see he more clearly through the slats in the fence. She's watchi him, her face like a porcelain doll's in the moonlight .
Did you? Did you really?

It was stupid. I shouldn't have done it. And I shouldn't have run ‘just now. I'ma fireman, they wouldn't have searched me. I'm not thinking clearly. I have to think. He hugs the gym bag to his chest, mind racing.
Are you scared?
I'll just give them back. Better yet, burn them. That's right, that's what I should do. Just tear out the pages and burn them myself.
Yes. That would probably be best. (pause) Can I see them? He hesitates, opens the gym bag, pulls out the books. She reaches through the slats, fingertips brushing the covers
"Charlie the Choo Choo." ,
If they ever found out...if they knew I had them...
I won't tell. Montag's shocked. Her words, so simple, have unlocked a door...as if she, of all people, had given him permission
You won't?
Not anybody. Not ever. He peers at her through the slats.

Really? She nods, her expression grave. Montag doesn't know what say. He looks down at the books, makes a decision. He eases "Charlie the Choo Choo" through the slats. Clari breath catches in her throat. She takes the book, almost to touch it. She looks to him, unable to believe it.
Make sure nobody finds that. I mean ever, ever. Okay? She draws the book toward her, but hesitates.
It's not a trick, is it? You won't come and burn our house, will you?
No. I won't. I promise. (beat) Clarisse. I'm really glad you're my friend. Really glad. Okay?
Okay. And then she's gone, off into the shadows. Montag shoves of the Flies" back in his bag, leaves his hiding place...
Millie's asleep in the dark. Montag eases onto the bed, s fully dressed, spoons up next to her. He's uncertain, sca needing to hold her. She stirs, groggy, half-asleep, as:
We burned a woman tonight.
You...what? You did what?
An old woman. She had a match. We didn't see it until it was too late.
So...she killed herself. She was crazy. A crazy old woman.
Yeah, I guess that's right. A crazy old woman.
You had me confused. (rolls away) Poor Guy. You must be tired. Try and get some sleep. She drifts off. Montag holds her a while, then eases to h side of the bed, mind going a mile-a-minute.
Montag enters, locks the door. He pulls "Lord of the Flie from his gym bag, examining it with fascination. He opens riffles the pages.
Paper. Ink. Words. So what? He sits, using the toilet for a chair, starts reading the very first page as we
The ANGLE hasn't changed, but we find Montag sprawled on floor in an exhausted sleep, the book lying nearby. Sudden POUNDING wrenches him awake. Millie" s muffled VOI heard through the door:
Guy, answer me! Are you all right in there?
Wha--yeah...yeah, m'all right... He sits up, trying to get his bearings, reeling from bein jolted from a deep sleep.
What are you doing in there? Open the door! His eyes focus, remembering where he is, sees the book ly on the floor. He grabs it and rises, fighting panic. MONTAG . Uh-huh, 'kay, just a minute...

No, now! I mean it! You've been in there all morning! You got me worried sick...and I have to pee! He jams the book in his waistband, hides it with his untu shirt. A quick glance in the mirror -- yup, he looks like hell. He opens the door. Millie muscles past him and make beeline for the toilet, sitting to pee.
-+-as Montag moves into the hallway, heart still pounding
Were you in here all night?
Yeah. Sorry. I was throwing up. I've come down with something. (beat) Would you call Captain Beatty and tell him I'm not coming in? The DOORBELL RINGS. He starts up the hallway to answer it
You can tell him yourself. That's probably him. ..-and he stops in his tracks, fully awake now, staring a the front door.
What? We hear the TOILET FLUSH. Millie exits the bathroom, sees Montag standing there. The DOORBELL RINGS again.
He called twice this morning, said he was coming over. You gonna answer it? He turns, pushes past her toward the bedroom.
No. Tell him I'm sick. Tell him to go away.
What? I can't tell him that! He's your boss!
Tell him I'm in bed! I've got chills! Fever! Just do it! Off her stunned look, he enters --

-- where he pulls the book and shoves it under his pillow He glances through the half-open bedroom door as he peels his clothes. He can see Millie at the far end of the hall b.g., talking to Beatty at the front door. She brings him this way. Montag jumps into bed. Moments l Beatty enters, trailed tentatively by Millie.
Sorry to hear you're sick.
I wanted to call. Ask for the night off.
By all means, take it. Your health is important. Beatty pulls up a chair, sits at bedside, eyeing Montag.
